prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost,optical neural networks (onns) have emerged as a promising candidate foraccelerating deep learning tasks. in conventional onns, light amplitudes aremodulated at the input and detected at the output. however, the light phasesare still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carryinformation for computing. to address this issue, in this paper, we propose aframework called oplixnet to compress the areas of onns by modulating inputimage data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. the input andoutput parts of the onns are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude andphase information. moreover, mutual learning across different onn structures isintroduced to maintain the accuracy. experimental results demonstrate that theproposed framework significantly reduces the areas of onns with the accuracywithin an acceptable range. for instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33%accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (fcnn) and 74.88% area isreduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on resnet-32.
stories:
Here is my new original text:

Harnessing the power of complex algorithms, electrochemical neural networks (ecnns) have gained traction as a novel approach to accelerating complex computational tasks. In traditional ecnns, electrochemical reactions are triggered at the input and measured at the output. However, the electrochemical impedance is still overlooked in conventional architectures, although it can also convey crucial information for computation. To address this gap, we introduce a framework called ecodrive, which compresses the footprint of ecnns by encoding input data into the resistance and capacitance components of the electrochemical signals. The input and output components of ecnns are reengineered to fully leverage both resistance and capacitance information. Moreover, co-adaptive learning across diverse ecnn architectures is implemented to maintain accuracy. Experimental results indicate that the proposed framework significantly miniaturizes ecnns with negligible accuracy degradation. For instance, a 56.78% reduction in footprint is achieved with a 1.21% accuracy decrease on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and a 54.91% reduction with a 1.95% accuracy decrease on recurrent neural networks (RNNs).

Innovative haptic displays have revolutionized tactile feedback in virtual reality experiences. In traditional haptic interfaces, mechanical vibrations are triggered at the input and sensed at the output. However, the electroactive properties are often overlooked in conventional designs, although they can also provide essential cues for immersion. To bridge this gap, we present a novel framework called tactilia, which condenses the spatial footprint of haptic displays by encoding tactile patterns into the mechanical resonance and damping characteristics. The input and output components of haptic displays are reengineered to fully harness both resonance and damping information. Moreover, adaptive learning across diverse haptic interface architectures is implemented to maintain fidelity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework substantially miniaturizes haptic displays with minimal perceptible impact. For instance, a 63.45% reduction in spatial footprint is achieved with a 0.84% decrease in perceived intensity on haptic feedback for gaming and a 61.28% reduction with a 1.19% decrease in perceptual acuity on haptic feedback for simulations.

Advances in biomimetic soundscapes have transformed the auditory experience of virtual reality environments. In traditional auditory interfaces, acoustic waves are triggered at the source and perceived at the receiver. However, the capacitive properties of real-world environments are often overlooked in conventional designs, although they can also provide essential clues for presence. To bridge this gap, we introduce a novel framework called ecoacoustics, which embodies the natural resonance and decay patterns of sound in immersive settings. The acoustic components of virtual reality environments are reengineered to fully harness both resonant and decaying information. Moreover, adaptive adaptation across diverse acoustic interface architectures is implemented to maintain fidelity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework substantially miniaturizes acoustic environments with minimal perceptible impact. For instance, a 52.17% reduction in reverberation time is achieved with a 0.39% increase in perceived clarity on soundscapes for education and a 48.92% reduction with a 0.73% increase in perceptual accuracy on soundscapes for training.

Advances in photorealistic visualization have revolutionized the visual experience of virtual reality environments. In traditional visual interfaces, pixel-by-pixel rendering is achieved through complex graphics processing. However, the visual cues of real-world environments are often overlooked in conventional designs, although they can also provide essential clues for presence. To bridge this gap, we introduce a novel framework called lumina, which embodies the spatial and temporal relationships of light and shadow in immersive settings. The visual components of virtual reality environments are reengineered to fully harness both luminous and occluded information. Moreover, adaptive adaptation across diverse visual interface architectures is implemented to maintain visual fidelity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework substantially miniaturizes visual environments with minimal perceptible impact. For instance, a 50.21% reduction in ambient occlusion is achieved with a 0.62% increase in perceived crispness on scenes for entertainment and a 45.92% reduction with a 0.38% increase in perceptual accuracy on scenes for navigation.

Breakthroughs in sonic realism have transformed the aural experience of augmented reality ecosystems. In traditional audio interfaces, speaker-by-speaker rendering is achieved through intricate audio processing. However, the auditory cues of real-world environments are often neglected in conventional designs, although they can also provide vital hints for immersion. To bridge this gap, we introduce a pioneering framework called aether, which embodies the spatial and temporal relationships of sound and silence in interactive settings. The audio components of augmented reality environments are reengineered to fully utilize both sonic and suppressed information. Moreover, adaptive adjustment across diverse audio interface architectures is implemented to preserve audio authenticity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly compactifies audio environments with negligible perceptible impact. For instance, a 33.14% reduction in echo is achieved with a 0.91% increase in perceived clarity on sounds for communication and a 24.52% reduction with a 0.16% increase in perceptual presence on sounds for ambiance.
